pieces

Class GamePiece

  • java.lang.Object
    • pieces.GamePiece
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Drawable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Artifact, Dragon, Dwarf, Elf, Knight, Maiden, Man, Orc, Sage, Skeleton, SkeletonKing, Trap, Unicorn, Witch, Wizard

    public abstract class GamePiece
extends java.lang.Object
implements Drawable

    GamePiece

    This is the abstract class that all other pieces are derived from. It includes an abstract method, getters and setters, and other methods. Includes legacy code from school project.
    Since:
    2017-10-31
    Version:
    2.0
    Author:
    Mark Baldwin, Cyndi Rader, Adam Nelson

      • GamePiece

        public GamePiece(char symbol,
                 java.awt.Point location)
        Constructor that all pieces use.
        Parameters:
        symbol - The symbol of the object on the board.

    • Method Detail

      • draw

        public void draw()
        Prints the symbol for the object onto the game board.
        Specified by:
        draw in interface Drawable

      • interact

        public abstract InteractionResult interact(Drawable[][] pieces,
                                           Player player)
        Abstract method, each piece interacts with the player differently.
        Parameters:
        pieces - The game board.
        player - The player object.
        Returns:
        InteractionResult Either NONE, GET_POINT, HIT, KILL, or ADVANCE.

      • getLocation

        public java.awt.Point getLocation()

      • setLocation

        public void setLocation(Drawable[][] pieces,
                        java.awt.Point newLocation)
        Determines if the new location trying to be passed is a valid. The location is only changed if it is still on the board. This changes where the piece "thinks" it is located.
        Parameters:
        pieces - The game board.
        newLocation - The desired new location.

      • movePiece

        public void movePiece(int x,
                      int y,
                      Drawable[][] pieces)
        This method changes the location of the piece on the board, and changes where it will actually be drawn. This changes where the piece "is actually" located.
        Parameters:
        x - The distance to be translated up or down on the board.
        y - The distance to be translated left or right on the board.
        pieces - The game board.

      • setSymbol

        public void setSymbol(char x)
